title: How much water exists on Earth, its atmospheres, and underground water deposits? Does it increase or decrease? - Quora

response.answer_text: First we present the (almost) obligatory water-drop graphic:  The mass of the oceans totals to about 1.4 × 10^21 kg, 10000 times the atmosphere’s water content. Note that they don’t mention the underground water resources. That is in large part because we really don’t know how much water is trapped in the crust and upper mantle. Some of that trapped water is captured molecule-by-molecule in the solids (much like “water of hydration” is trapped in concrete). Some studies have suggested that there’s an equivalent amount of water underground as there is on the surface. The usual number i see cited is 30% of fresh water is underground (10.5 million km3) and over twice that amount of saline (23.4 million km3). Those two amounts are included in the 1.4 billion of the graphic. As the oceanic tectonic plates are dragged into the earth at subduction zones, they’re also carrying down saturated layers of ocean sediment. Much of that water returns to the surface as steam components of volcanic eruptions … including as the “foaming agent” of pumice. Since water is a by-product of the combustion of hydrocarbons (such as oil, natural gas (methane) and gasoline/petrol), it is continuously created as we burn those fuels. When plants photosynthesize, they’re “consuming” water to create the sugars they will metabolize later in the process of respiration. At that time they’ll release water vapor … but those are “new” molecules instead of the old ones that were used earlier. Some of the consumed water will end up as the plant’s structure (such as wood). As others have written, some water is, indeed, lost to space … this happens when the sun’s ultraviolet light breaks apart those few water molecules high in the atmosphere. First it knocks off one hydrogen ion, which is lost to space. Then the remaining HO- radical can get broken down and the second hydrogen is lost. Whether or not the lone oxygen atom manages to couple with another to create a neutral O2 molecule is a roll of the dice. But the “water” that was there before is now gone. (Don’t worry too much … the sun’s “solar wind” is blowing a continuous stream of hydrogen ions in our direction that will help replenish the lost hydrogen. But it’s still a net loss).

I won’t argue with the posts citing the volumes of water in, on, and floating around the Earth because, for the most part, they’re are fairly much in agreement. What I’m not seeing much of is the answer to “Does it (the amount of water) increase or decrease? It’s decreasing. I can provide evidence of this from a satellite picture :  “This is an ultraviolet image of Earth's dark hemisphere with the Sun behind it, taken from NASA’s Dynamic Explorer I spacecraft at 19,700 km altitude above 13° N latitude, on February 16,1982. The extended red glow around the planet comes from hydrogen atoms that have escaped to the exosphere. A northern auroral oval and equatorial glow are due to emission from atomic oxygen and molecular nitrogen. Isolated points are stars that are bright in the ultraviolet.” (From Catling & Zahnle, “The escape of planetary atmospheres”, Scientific American, 2009, photograph courtesy of NASA). The picture provides evidence that the earth is shedding hydrogen to outer space. Although the Earth is able to maintain most of the hydrogen, as the escape velocity from Earth (10.8 km/sec at the exobase), is usually much higher that what hydrogen atoms can achieve (at 1000 K, hydrogen atoms have an average speed of 5 km/sec,). Still, the dissociation of water molecules release enough hydrogen to appear in these photos, or about 102,500 tons of terrestrial hydrogen that escape each year. As the Earth is not getting back nearly this amount from outer space, I would conclude that the Earth is slowly drying up.
